item.title: A Resident Evil Requiem pull-up bar bundle sold out in Japan in less than five hours, and honestly, it just makes sense
item.content:encoded: Capcom has teamed up with a Japanese TV shopping channel, and it's beautifully absurd.

item.title: If I had just set a new world record for GPU overclocking, I'd surely be making a lot more fuss about it than AMD has
item.content:encoded: Hitting 4,769 MHz on any GPU is no small feat.

item.title: The best Geralt, Doug Cockle, completed The Witcher 3, got the best ending, and was driven 'bonkers' by the Bloody Baron quest
item.content:encoded: And now we know he's got a thing for red heads.

item.title: Acer and Asus' German websites are down in wake of lawsuit, but Acer says its own will 'be up again shortly' so customers can get BIOS updates again
item.content:encoded: Updating BIOS is already a pain as is.

item.title: Some users are claiming Discord's default process priorities are causing performance problems in esports games, so I've tested it myself to see what's going on
item.content:encoded: And I have to say, I can't see any serious issues at all.

item.title: Microsoft's AI PC beginner's guide demonstrates how convoluted its branding has become, but hey, at least 'AI is not here to replace you'
item.content:encoded: It's very simple, let me just break out this whiteboard.

item.title: WoW dev was surprised that players 'like being jumped' by the upcoming Prey system—even on its hardest difficulty, where 'going AFK might get you killed'
item.content:encoded: "Players really liked being ambushed."

item.title: Nioh 3 has sold over 1 million copies in two weeks, breaking Team Ninja's record and carrying the series to 10 million sales
item.content:encoded: We were all hungry for a new soulslike to kick off the year, I guess.

item.title: Kick off the year of the horse with a stableful of discounted horse games in Steam Horse Fest
item.content:encoded: Start horsing around.

item.title: A redditor claims to have found a horrifying, AI-generated, multi-limbed figure in a rental house listing photo and it's exactly the sort of Phasmophobia-style jump scare I didn't need this morning
item.content:encoded: Why you so spooky, AI?

item.title: 'Our most uncompromising keyboard ever built': Razer has unveiled a new signature edition version of its Huntsman keyboard, but I can't get over the price
item.content:encoded: That's a lot of cash.

item.title: We're getting even more free lootboxes and a double XP weekend in Overwatch just for playing the game
item.content:encoded: Season 1's a hit, I'd say.

item.title: Street Fighter 2 producer Yoshiki Okamoto now makes gacha games and spends half a million dollars on each 'to make sure the people who spend the most don't end up dissatisfied'
item.content:encoded: You have to think like a whale to catch a whale. I'm pretty sure Herman Melville said that.

item.title: Life is Strange developer Don't Nod adds a dash of Alien: Isolation anxiety to its usual cinematic formula, and I think it works
item.content:encoded: Ariane is a scientist through and through.

item.title: Blood Bowl creator Jervis Johnson agrees with Games Workshop's AI ban, says 'it allows you to be a bit lazy and not put in the effort'
item.content:encoded: "AI is going to be like the asbestos of the internet and the computer industry."

item.title: 'Art and science and procreation, that's about all life is good for:' Two former freeware developers are still trying to keep it weird in an era when companies 'sell games to people in 5-second clips'
item.content:encoded: "These money people need numbers to know they will make their money back, which kind of conflicts with the nature of experimentation and trying to push the boundaries of the medium."

item.title: An Elite Dangerous player discovered a way to write new stories into the margins of the 12-year-old space sandbox, and now thousands are testing it
item.content:encoded: How the nearly 9,000 players on the Distant Worlds 3 expedition are contributing to the birth of something new.

item.title: Judging by the GPT-4o situation, game developers will have a big problem if they get serious about AI chatbot NPCs
item.content:encoded: Balance patches that tweak guns and spells can enrage players. What if what you're re-balancing is their romantic partner?

item.title: Arc Raiders' next update adds hurricanes, and players think the teaser is hiding a new Arc enemy too
item.content:encoded: Also, beards.

item.title: Stop Killing Games is launching NGOs in the European Union and the US: 'We're not just going away on this'
item.content:encoded: This whole thing is becoming a much bigger deal than anyone expected.

item.title: Dutch defense secretary says 'you can jailbreak an F-35 just like an iPhone,' and I'm here to tell the Dutch defense secretary that this is a great opportunity to run Doom on a fighter jet
item.content:encoded: I know there are probably bigger priorities, but come on.

item.title: One of the best puzzle games ever is getting surprise DLC even though its developer kind of closed a while ago
item.content:encoded: Opus Magnum is a puzzle classic, and soon it's getting DLC that's "around half the length" of the original campaign.

item.title: The next Witcher spin-off game is about Dandelion sharing his version of Geralt's adventures with the world: 'you might encounter a stuffed unicorn'
item.content:encoded: Reigns: The Witcher is being made in collaboration with CD Projekt Red.

item.title: Diablo 2 player discovers the key to immortality on the new warlock class is to use a pet demon as a shield
item.content:encoded: Don't tell Blizzard!

item.title: Surprise: Slay the Spire 2 is bringing 4-player co-op when it hits early access on March 6
item.content:encoded: Ah, good. An audience for my poor decisions.

item.title: XCOM designer Jake Solomon announces surprise closure of his studio alongside a first look at its canceled life sim, 'the game we poured our hearts into'
item.content:encoded: "Burbank" was set to be a life sim with dramatic storylines.

item.title: First Monopoly, then Catan, and now Netflix has announced a movie based on the Ticket to Ride board game
item.content:encoded: Maybe we'll eventually get a fantasy drama called Game of Checkers.

item.title: The many-boxed roadmap represents everything I hate about shooters right now
item.content:encoded: Our relationship with the biggest shooters around have contorted from player to investor.

item.title: If you've ever had a crippling Vampire Survivors or Slay the Spire habit, avoid Vampire Crawlers at all costs
item.content:encoded: Or play it, and let it consume your whole Steam Next Fest week. I'm not your dad.

item.title: Ubisoft lays off 40 people at its Toronto studio, reassures everyone who remembers the Splinter Cell remake that the Splinter Cell remake is still happening
item.content:encoded: The Ubisoft restructuring continues to extract a brutal human toll.

item.title: Bluepoint Games, Sony's famed remaster studio, is being closed as the fallout from PlayStation's disastrous pivot to live service continues
item.content:encoded: The unexpected shutdown follows the cancellation of a live service God of War game Bluepoint was working on.

item.title: Arc Raiders full interview: 'Nobody whatsoever thought we'd have this many players'
item.content:encoded: Embark's thoughts on matchmaking, the state of PvPvE, and the future of its ambitious live-service extraction shooter.

item.title: Beyerdynamic MMX 150 Wireless gaming headset review
item.content:encoded: Excellent in many regards, but it's got some stiff competition to worry about.

item.title: Saving blueprints after an Expedition isn't 'off the table', says Arc Raiders' director, but Embark is also looking at alternatives
item.content:encoded: Imagine the scenario: Do you keep the Looting Mk. 3 (Survivor) or the Anvil?

item.title: 'Preserving the web is not the problem. Losing it is,' claims the director of the Internet Archive
item.content:encoded: "The Wayback Machine is built for human readers."

item.title: Highguard website woes are just an administrative thing, developer says, and the studio is in no rush to fix it because 'reputational damage' is already done
item.content:encoded: The Highguard website has been unavailable for almost a week.

item.title: One leaker's cryptic post suggests that AMD's next Ryzen lineup will have some serious core configurations across the range
item.content:encoded: From a six-core entry-level chip, all the way up to a dual-CCD, 24-core range topper.

item.title: 13-year-old Decima engine allows Death Stranding team to 'accomplish many things that would be difficult to achieve elsewhere'
item.content:encoded: No wonder Aloy is in Death Stranding.

item.title: PC sales of High On Life were just behind PlayStation, the 'lead platform,' but Xbox trailed behind despite its 7-month console exclusivity deal
item.content:encoded: Silver medal for PC.

item.title: My favourite thing about Linux gaming will now automagically apply crucial fan patches to your Metal Gear installs, making it even easier than on Windows
item.content:encoded: Luxtorpeda is chugging along.

item.title: At a mere 2 square micrometers in size, this is the world's smallest QR code and it's 'smaller than most bacteria'
item.content:encoded: You don't happen to have a microscopic phone camera yet, do you?

item.title: WoW lead says they 'lost something along the way' by building dungeons for sweaty Mythic+ timers instead of 20-boss mazes like the good old days, but Labyrinths could be the solution
item.content:encoded: "Labyrinths are trying to tap into [that]."

item.title: League of Legends might be adding public voice chat—and as someone with a combined 2,655 hours in Dota 2 and Deadlock, I can safely say: Oh no
item.content:encoded: You are not prepared.

item.title: Microsoft says its glass-based storage project now works with 'the same material found in kitchen cookware and oven doors' and can hold data for 10,000 years
item.content:encoded: Served on a platter.

item.title: Understandable AI paranoia has inspired a developer to change the handcrafted character art in its upcoming sim: 'They look a bit AI'
item.content:encoded: Transport Fever 3's characters look pretty uncanny, and that's a bigger problem than it used to be.

item.title: Nvidia dumps its $140 million stake in Arm but licensing deals remain and its new PC CPU is still go
item.content:encoded: Nvidia once planned to take full control of Arm.

item.title: Birdwatching Notebook is meant to be a relaxing idler, but it drove me to new depths of unlock-obsessed birdmania
item.content:encoded: Birds of a feather flock together as long as you've placed a berry bush.

item.title: The new game from Disco Elysium's studio feels like the first Christmas after your parents' divorce
item.content:encoded: It ain't never gonna be what it was.

item.title: I romanced a hunky British man with a shotgun for a head in a game that lets me have 'US government approved pronouns' like Jamestown, grits, and freedom
item.content:encoded: Polyarmory: High-Calibre Love is one of the funniest, stupidest, most incredible names for a videogame I've ever seen.

item.title: Dutch police have arrested a man for reportedly refusing to relinquish files they sent him: 'He would only comply if he received something in return'
item.content:encoded: Note to self, don't download files from the police and refuse to send them back.
